name: Customers care chat services
body:
Greetings,Â 

As most of you probably know, we went live with our chat services for all customers back on August 2nd!Â Â 

Many of you have already used this great chat service! We are incredibly happy that this channel of communication has been helping our customers - and the feedback from the surveys we received reinforces that belief.Â Â 

Chat support is designed to provide fast answers to how-to questions, assist with small or large issues, speed up information-gathering, and even follow up on an existing case â€” all in real-time.

In fact, more than 40% of the inquiries and concerns that are being reported to us over the chat are being solved live in the same chat session in which the issue was reported.Â This is a great Time for Resolution achievement that we are happy and proud to provide to our customers with. Thus, we encourage many of you that haven't taken this service for a test drive yet (including our Platinum tier customers) to give it a try!

So.....

Where is it available: The new live chat module is available on the homepage of the Customer Care Portal: https://support.kaltura.com/. Chat is available only for those of you who have access to the Customer Care Portal and permission to open tickets and inquires prior to the Chat service going live.Â 

When is it available: Chat module is available during both EMEA and US business hours.Â 

How does it work: We have a dedicated Chat Support team in place to cater this new service.Â 

Is there a cost for chat support? We have decided to include this premium service in customersâ€™ existing service packages.

Providing you with the best possible service is our continued goal and commitment.Â Use this service and share your feedback with us!

Happy chatting!

name: Blur or Background Options for Kaltura Meetings
body:
It would be so nice for our students in our school to be able to blur their backgrounds or use a filter while on camera in the Kaltura meeting room. Is this something that Kaltura can provide like Zoom does?

This is really an issue of equity so that students do not feel that showing their environment would be embarrassing.

Thanks!

name: [Kaltura Meetings / Virtual Classroom] Add Button to Record All Breakout Rooms
body:
One of the most common questions we receive about Kaltura Virtual Classroom is "Can I record breakout rooms?" While the answer is "yes"...it is follow by "but...you have to do this...or have someone do this..."

Yes, we can record breakout rooms, but the teacher, or someone present in the breakout room, has to go into each room and initiate the recording. If it is not the teacher, they have to remember to share that recording. Our teachers often note that they miss portions of the conversation as they are jumping from room to room to begin the recording.

It would be a huge improvement to be able to click a button and initiate a recording of all breakout rooms at once.

name: Asset Report
body: We've been using Kaltura Mediaspace throughout our enterprise for almost 10 years. We have channels and categories with hundreds of videos. While analytic reports offer content owners reports on "Top Content", these reports are still based on views/plays. What about the content getting uploaded and never, ever, played. Nobody wants that to be the case, but it happens--like all of those team meetings that are recorded "in case someone missed it"... I am routinely asked if there were an easy way to get a report of all the content published to a category or channel--a content inventory list. Ideally this list would be similar to the Top Content report in that it would include, Entry ID, Name, Creation Date, Creator --but also include Collaborators (lets face it people leave our company or change roles), Update date, and maybe total plays, and views. This Content Inventory list would be particularly helpful to groups looking to overhaul their video content completely, or for teams that undergo a reorg.

name: Status of V7 Player Beta
body:
Last year there was a great presentation in the August 24th office hours about the V7 player and the work that was happening to get all of the plugins ready. At the time, the product manger shared that they were planning an Early Adopter/Beta program that was hoped to be available in mid-October. My understanding is that program has been delayed and hasn't yet started.

From that discussion, my understanding was that the player was basically production ready and that the primary limitation was around the extensions that still need to be made V7 player compatible.

I have had access to a version of the player since 2020 and we love it - even with the plugin limitations. That said, we have have struggled to get a certain answer about the upgradeability of the player we are using to the final version.

We are starting to prepare for fall courses and I would love to get an update to get a sense of whether we could possible start using that player more widely (even with the existing limitations) to take advantage of some of the great feature and improved user experience that it provides.

Does anyone have any updates on the status of the V7 player or the early adopter program?

name: Exporting your KMS and/or KAF configs
body:
Sometimes it would be useful for an admin to be able to export their KMS and/or KAF config to a file, especially if you are managing multiple instances (perhaps for something like a PROD and a TEST/DEV setup) and you'd like to compare settings to see what is different.

The following url syntax can be used for downloading your config:

https://{YOUR_KAF_OR_KMS_URL}/admin/export-config?ks={VALID_ADMIN_KS}

You can generate a valid ADMIN KS using the TestMe or Developer console.

After getting your KS and executing the above url against your KMS/KAF instance, this will download your config as an .ini file with an associative array of settings. Using this, along with a diff tool of your choice (there are many online tools, but I've personally used https://winmerge.org/?lang=en in the past with good results), you could then easily compare config files to find differences between your setups and know exactly where to go to rebase your configs if you'd like to maintain parity between instance settings.

name: Support more than 10 playlists with Channel or Media Gallery import
body:
This is the ticket we received today from an instructor: Why are playlists NOT important (to Kaltura)? There's only two things in there, videos and playlists, please make the imports helpful. I've got 90 videos in 25 playlists that are to be used every semester, but when I import media assets, it purposefully skips importing playlists.

---

This has been a long-standing (forever) limitation: importing a channel or Media Gallery with more than 10 playlists will not import any of the playlists.

In this day of Kaltura AWS infrastructure and an increased reliance on video for education education, this limitation is unacceptable. It is not good customer experience to expect those who use playlists extensively to spend a ton of time rebuilding them each term in exchange for some perceived bandwidth limitation on the data center side of things.

I've submitted an official Feature Request *again* (Case 00368345), though I'm sure there are already plenty of the same request out there from others.

Let's vote this up and push Kaltura to remove this old limitation and get out of the data the dark ages.

Thank you!

body:

We have moderators/managers that curate several to many channels and galleries, and managing all these tasks simply from the email notifications is proving to be challenging at scale. Other than the email notification, the only way to find videos that require moderation approval is to click through to each channel the manager owns.

Having a centralized place in KMS to review, approve, reject, etc. moderated entries would be a huge UX boon for our category managers! This could take on the same UI/UX as the My Media page, only instead of showing all your media, the page only shows a list of videos you need to approve/reject.

name: White space below Kaltura content embedded via Canvas RCE?
body:
Our users have long been frustrated by the white space that is present when they embed a player that includes the transcript plug-in. As a partial solution we provided a player that has the transcript expanded to start, so that the white space isn't so big when the page first loads. However, it seems that now there's much more white space below even the expanded transcript. Looks like, regardless of the embedsize used, the video automatically "takes up" around 824 pixels; this means tons of white space: e.g. if the user selects the smallest size (304x231), they get around 350 pixels of white space below the transcript box. It's not quite as bad for larger embedsizes, but even with the largest default one (608x402) there's still something like 180 pixels of white space below the expanded transcript.

Is this happening to anybody else?

And more importantly: if it's not happening to you, would you share how you've set things up (in KMC Studio and in Browseandembed) so that you can provide a player without all the white space (while still providing students a way to view the transcript)?

Thanks,

Judy Stern (UC Berkeley)

name: Uploading Videos using kaltura.services.uploadToken.upload
body:
I am trying to upload a video using:

  kaltura.services.uploadToken.upload(uploadTokenId, fileData, resume, finalChunk, resumeAt)

The fileData parameter requires a string path to the file to be uploaded. If I provide a hard-coded string, this works fine. However, I would like for my application to use a file picker (e.g. <input type="file"...) to select the file to upload to Kaltura. When doing so, modern browsers obfuscate the file path.

Is there another API, or kaltura.services.uploadToken function I can use that will accept an actual File type rather than the string path to the file?

Using the uploadToken.upload function, the only solutions I have come up with so far are to have users create a video folder in their C:/Users folder (/Users for Mac) and have them always upload videos from there - or, do a double upload to a server where I know the file path/url and provide that.

Is there another solution I haven't thought of?

Thanks!

name: Is there such thing as a Kaltura equivalent to YouTube's "miniplayer" feature?
body:
Hi All,

We are interested in replicating YouTube's "miniplayer" functionality in Kaltura.

https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/9162927?hl=en&co=GENIE.Platform%3DDesktop

In YouTube, when a user clicks the miniplayer button, the video player is moved to the lower right hand corner of the page (sort of like picture in picture) and "floats" above the page content. This allows the user to scroll the page while the video playback continues, anchored in the lower right.

The miniplayer is not resizable and cannot be moved, instead it is anchored in place and floats over the page content.

We can see a use case where having "miniplayer" functionality in Kaltura would be handy for Students scrolling course content within the LMS while at the same time being able to watch a lecture.

Does anyone know if such a feature exists in the Kaltura ecosystem? Perhaps there is a plugin? Has anyone tried this before? What are your thoughts?

Thank you!

Best,

Chris

name: Upgrade path for players to move a player from V2 to V7
body: Following our discussion from Office Hours on August 10th 2021, posing the idea of some type of migration mechanism that would allow for the upgrade of a V2 player to V7. This will be critically important for users that have used embed codes that specify a particular player id (uiconfid), such as BSE embeds within an LMS, or even KMC embed codes used in external application and sites. Without some type of mechanism to allow for upgrading a player from V2 to V7, then users will be left with an arduous task of replacing embed codes to get V7 functionality.

name: Uploading Closed Caption File using the API
body:
I am trying to upload an SRT file and associate it with an existing video. When I run the following code, the file uploads. However, when I go to the video in question in the KMC and go to Captions, the status shows as Processing and the processing never completes. What am I doing wrong?

Thanks for any help you can provide!

export async function uploadCaption() {
  const uploadToken = new kaltura.objects.UploadToken();
  try {
    kaltura.services.uploadToken
      .add(uploadToken) // add the token
      .execute(client)
      .then(addedToken => {
        const uploadTokenId = addedToken.id;
        const fileData = callbackParams.path;
        const resume = false;
        const finalChunk = true;
        const resumeAt = -1;
        kaltura.services.uploadToken
          .upload(uploadTokenId, fileData, resume, finalChunk, resumeAt) // upload using the token
          .execute(client)
          .then(uploadedToken => {
            const captionAsset = new kaltura.objects.CaptionAsset();
            captionAsset.accuracy = 100;
            captionAsset.displayOnPlayer = true;
            captionAsset.format = 1;
            captionAsset.isDefault = 0;
            captionAsset.label = 'English';
            captionAsset.language = 'English'
            captionAsset.objectType = 'KalturaCaptionAsset';
            captionAsset.sourceParams = 1;
            captionAsset.description = 'This is a caption';
            captionAsset.mediaParserType = 0;
            captionAsset.name = 'My Captions';
            captionAsset.partnerId = process.env.KALTURA_PARTNER_ID;
            captionAsset.remoteStorageProfileIds = '';
            captionAsset.requiredPermissions = '';
            captionAsset.sourceAssetParamsIds = '';
            captionAsset.sourceRemoteStorageProfileId = 0;
            captionAsset.systemName = '';
            captionAsset.tags = '';
            kaltura.services.captionAsset
              .add(callbackParams.videoId>, captionAsset) // add a caption entry
              .execute(client)
              .then(captionEntry => {
                console.log("CAPTION ENTRY", captionEntry)
              })
              .catch(Error => {
                kalturaError = Error;
              });
          });
      });
  } catch (Error) {
    kalturaError = Error;
  }
}

name: Are you machine captions defaulting to Indonesian today (Sunday 3/27)

The only problem is that in KAF and KMS the English language choice no longer exists and is defaulting instead to Indonesian.

It's worth pointing out that we don't auto machine caption our uploads. User's order their own machine captions.

We've cross posted this in the Kaltura Owners list and we've opened Case 00403250 to find out what's going on.

name: BUG: IVQ grading errors for multiple attempt quizzes
body:
Hi, team,

We've opened Case 00400357 today to report that the quiz users analytics IVQ final score and the attempt results data do not match up when the IVQ is set to allow multiple attempts. The latest attempt data will show the results, but that data is not being pushed to the gradebook or being reflected in the analytics.

It's not clear to me if this impacts all LTI integrations, or just Canvas.

The feedback we received from Customer Care is that they identified a bug, the fix is in QA, and expected to be deployed in 2 weeks.

I've shared with them already that a two week delay for a problem that affects student grades is unacceptable. I've not heard back yet on whether or not this fix will happen sooner than two weeks or not.

So, check your IVQs, and reach out to support to let them know if you are impacted.

name: Is anyone "auditing" the accuracy of Human CC from Verbit
body:
I know we don't really have time for this, BUT -- how can we trust the accuracy if there is no auditing?

Given we are contracting through Kaltura, I would hope they had some process in place. Nonetheless, I recently audited a video and found a 2.5% error rate. The instructor was not a native English speaker, but spoke at a reasonable pace and was clear. This was a financial accounting lecture and she was basically "reading" from the PPT so it was pretty easy to determine what she was saying with a little effort.

Missed corrections included "cause" should have been "cost/s", "cells" should have been "sales", "verbal" should have been "variable", and many others.

I'd love to hear what others are experiencing.

Maureen

name: Feature Idea: Video Quiz (IVQ) Analytics and filtering
body:
I've submitted a Feature Request for this in the Support Portal (Case 00357619) but I wanted to reach out here for discussion, too.

There are two IVQ analytics data issues that are related to each other and plague our users:

1. Instructors may want to know when a student answered questions, especially when no grade passback is configured, but that data is not included in the Quiz Questions / Quiz Users pages or exports.

Â (example below where a test student submitted this response before the date filters I applied).


2. Faculty often import course content from a prior term and it never occurs to them to replace IVQ assignments with a fresh copy of an IVQ. This means that when they go to look at analytics, the data is populated with all the submissions from the prior term(s) and they have no way toÂ filter for the specific course roster of students. If there were a working date filter option (the filter on "regular" Analytics doesn't seem to apply), the media owner could filter out prior submissions.

The workaround right now involves downloaded reports and Excel vlookup wizardry with the course gradebook export, or heaven help us, deep API wizardry.

Cheers !

Melinda Kraft, University of Michigan

name: Tool to Identify Embedded Kaltura Video IDs
body:
At Utah State University we often have a need to identify the video ID of a video that is embedded on a page - in our case, mostly Canvas pages. Right now we generally do that by viewing the course code and tracking down the entry ID there which can be cumbersome and overwhelming for people not familiar with HTML.

To make that process easier, one of our student developers - Kade Howes, has built a Chrome Extension that you can click on to identify the Video ID of an embedded Kaltura Video:

The plugin is functional, but we are still working through a couple of challenges - especially when it comes to identifying some playlists depending on how they are embedded. We hope to eventually make it available in the Chrome Extensions Store, but in the meantime - let us know if you are interested in this tool, especially if you might be interested in contributing to the code. Here is a quick video of the tool in action:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6WHzIQCNV-k

I will update this post when the tool is generally available (assuming Google approves it!)

name: Being able to upload more than one entry to "My media" at once
body:
Hello,

I have tried to review all the proposals so as not to repeat something already requested.

We think it's a good idea that a normal user (not KMC admin) can upload more than one entry to My Media at a time, in the same way that it can be done from KMC.

If multiple files are chosen to be uploaded to My Media, only one is loaded (in MediaSpace). In fact, in an LMS you can only choose one entry. It is true that while uploading an entry you can choose another, but the idea would be to be able to choose several files as from KMC -> Create -> Upload from desktop.

It is a request demanded by teachers and that we believe is useful and could be added as a configuration option in KAF.

Regards, Luis

name: Zoom/Kaltura integration: Do not publish automatically publish PMI recordings to a LMS Media Gallery
body:
Greeting Everyone!

On August 16th, Penn State took the jump and fully embraced the newest Zoom/Kaltura Marketplace Integration. Not only did we upgrade it... We also configured it to automatically add Zoom recordings, created in the Zoom LTI in Canvas, to the course's Media Gallery.

This is how it works! Typically, when an instructor schedules a meeting using the Zoom LTI, tracking_fields are attached to meeting ID information.Â Â These tracking_fields are used for many reasons in Zoom.Â Â Specifically, for Kaltura, they contain which Course Media Gallery (which is a Category in Kaltura) that meeting belongs to.Â Â This information helps direct the Zoom recordings created with that meeting ID to the Courseâ€™s Media Gallery in Kaltura.

Overall, instructors and course designers LOVE the updated integration and it's magic when it publish to the Media Gallery! It's a great time saver and really helps our effort to phase out our university's dependence on Zoom cloud storage.

However we found a problem with it...

When an instructor schedules a meeting in Canvas using their Personal Meeting ID (PMI) it attaches the course's tracking_fields to their PMI meeting information. This causes any additional recordings made with that PMI (regardless of if they are made within the course, a different course, or outside of Canvas entirely) to populate in the original courseâ€™s media gallery automatically.

This is a HUGE issue because that PMI could be used for recording meetings that may not pertain to the course (i.e., private meetings with students, non-instructional related meetings, etc.) and should not automatically populate the Courseâ€™s Media Gallery. It violates privacy and FERPA policies. We have brought this issue up with Kaltura a few weeks ago (which we've detailed in the attached document) and provided a possible solution.

As a workaround, we are recommending faculty to not to use their PMI for class recordings. We also developed a script that is leveraging Kaltura and Zoom APIs to monitor each Zoom recording that comes into Kaltura. It checks if the Zoom Meeting ID is a person's PMI and removes it from the Media Gallery right away. If the instructor's intent to publish those recordings to their course's Media Gallery in Canvas, they will have to add it manually.

Our idea here is: Do not allow recordings created with a person Personal Meeting ID (PMI) to automatically publish to a LMS Media Gallery.

Our Kaltura case number on this request is: 00357265

What is the community's thoughts on this idea?

Kaltura-Zoom-PMI-Recs-in-CMG.pdf

name: Cookies Issue Blocking KAF Access on Firefox (from listserv)
body:
~carrying this conversation over from the listserv for increased exposure~

Original post (Wed Jan 12 09:46:49 PST 2022)â€“ "After updating Firefox (96) I'm now seeing "It seems your browser is blocking 3rd party session cookies<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_cookie#Session_cookie> which are required for the Kaltura application. To resolve this issue, please update your settings to allow 3rd party cookies" for Kaltura integrated/embedded content in Canvas. I've added our domain as an exception (the shield with the slash), but the message/error remains."

Since then, six others have chimed in on the issue. OP has vanity domain setup; others with vanity domain setup are not experiencing the issue. I have reports of the issue and we do not have vanity domain.

From my chat with Customer Care about the issue: "Currently there is an issue with Firefox 96.0 blocking third party cookies..." [Case# 00387862]

From Firefox 96 release notes: "Firefox will now default all cookies to having a SameSite=lax attribute which helps defend against Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attacks."

Indeed if you look in the Firefox dev tools during a request to Media Gallery (that results in "enable cookies" error message) (no vanity domain here):

Because I also have two users reporting this issue using the latest version of Chrome (one on Windows, one on Mac), I wanted to compare what shows in Firefox for the request to what shows in Chrome.

The following is from a successful request (I have not been able to replicate the issue in Chrome thus far):

I do not have enough web dev knowledge (yet) to know if this is related, but one part of the latest Chrome release notes is "Chrome disables WebSQL in third-party contexts."

I'm hoping Kaltura will shed some additional light on this issue for us very, very soon. We started a new term this week and it irks me to not have "in the meantime" fix to provide students facing this issue.

Does anyone have additional insights on a fix? Or strategies for how to handle this with impacted users?

Thanks in advance.

Cameron Z.

name: Add Media Gallery import handling for users with more than 100 Canvas enrollments
body:
Note: I don't know if other LMS integration manifest this issue ast he Canvas API is a contributing factor.

The Canvas KAF Media Gallery import process retrieves a list of enrollments for the teacher and presents a list of courses the user to import from.

Now that we are 7 years into Canvas and the KAF, some of our instructors have more than 100 enrollments in any role (teacher or other roles). The problem at hand is two-fold:

  1. The Canvas API returns a paginated list all enrollments for the user, regardless of their role, sorted in no discernable order (max results is 100 per page, which is a Canvas API performance limitation).
  2. That KAF is not checking for multiple pages of enrollments results, so is only presenting a filtered (for teacher roles) list of the first 100 rows of unsorted results.

Then end result is what appears to be a broken list of importable Media Galleries, where some old and/or new Media Galleries are not presented (because of the unsorted response from Canvas and/or the results are in a different "page" of Canvas API results).

To the user, this looks like there is something wrong with the missing course galleries, but it is really a result of short-sighted code development on the Kaltura side combined with a messy API response from Canvas.

Customer Care informed me that a feature request exists to fix this behavior. From my perspective, this feels more like a bug than feature request worthy, but semantics aside, this needs to be fixed sooner rather than later.

Please consider adding your support here to help push this forward.

In the meantime, we KMC admins are directing our high use users to contact us for support so we can publish the media to the appropriate galleries via the KMC.

name: CC Label Suffix: Add Separate Row for Machine 'Alignment' Jobs
body:
~~Background~~

A January 2021 KMC update "added the ability to set a suffix to the caption's label. The label suffix may be add separately for human captions and machine generated caption."

And per the respective Knowledge Center article: "Machine captions label suffix - Select whether to generate a label suffix. ... The label is displayed in the Captions tab."

What neither the release notes update nor the Knowledge Center article makes clear, though, is that when you turn on the machine captions label suffix, the label applies to both machine "Captions" jobs and machine "Alignment" jobs.

("For Alignment: request for captions based on a transcript file (txt). The system will align the txt with the video..." â€“ read more on this KC article.)

~~Our Setup~~

Our institution develops and authors scripts for the videos we produce for our courses. We submit a .txt version of a video's script for machine Alignment, giving us the wonderful result of ~100% accurate CC for the video.

We also have the auto-machine-caption-all-media setting turned on for our account. (I know there is active discussion about the pros/cons of this, but we have it turned on still for now.)

When the CC label suffix feature was released, I was excited to turn on it on so that the auto-generated machine captions could be identified by users (via the suffix).

When I turned it on for testing, however, I quickly observed that the label applies to the CC of machine "Alignment" jobs as well. And since we use the Alignment feature for our course videos as described above, having the CC label say "English (auto-generated)" would not be accurate.

~~The Idea~~

In the REACH Profiles and Services Service Parameters settings in the KMC, add one more parameter row beneath "Machine captions label suffix" called "Machine alignment label suffix."

Users (KMC admins) can then select to enable a label suffix for the "Captions" jobs or the "Alignment" jobs, or both. And in this setup the label could be different for each, of course.

If this configuration was available right now I'd turn it on in our account today.


â­ Thank you for considering my idea.

name: "Access Denied" errors when accessing Media Gallery - Important Update
body:
Hi everyone,

WeÂ have receivedÂ reports from a few customers regarding â€œAccess deniedâ€ errors when accessing content in a Media Gallery.

WhileÂ this is not affecting all customers and many accounts, and whileÂ teams are investigating this with high priority, we did want to bring this to your attention for the following reason/Â benefits in case you do come across this issue of â€œAccess Deniedâ€ error message received when users try to access â€œMedia Galleryâ€ category in LMS such as Canvas, D2L, BB etcâ€¦ (not KMS/KMC).

  1. A workaround is availableÂ -Â the affectedÂ â€œMedia Galleryâ€Â categoryÂ shouldÂ be re-indexed to resolve the issue.Â Re indexing can happen just by the virtue of changing any metadata fields (name, description, tags, etcâ€¦).Â 
  2. The issue may also be with a sub-category under â€œMedia Galleryâ€, the above workaround should be applied in such scenario.
  3. On the other hand, our teamsÂ that are working to solve this issue can benefit fromÂ more informationÂ and examplesÂ to expedite investigation. If this is a new report, please hold off on applying the workaroundÂ (i.e. #1 or #2 above)Â and provide us a log file collected while the error is shown. Steps to collect the log file (.har) can be found here:Â http://knowledge.kaltura.com/faq/how-capture-network-traffic-logs-kaltura-support. Open a support ticket and include the log file.

We will update here once new information is available and when a solution is in place. In case of an increase in scale we will include updates on ourÂ StatusÂ Page.

Thank you for your patience and help in reporting this issue!

Cc; @Judy @Willa @FrankE @rgibbs @paulhyde @Paul_Rickards @ascales78 @sportoulas @kpritchard @ckong11 @astokes @kkath @L_A_Plays_Itself @jrodgers @michlew @sdicks @stephanieng @sharin @yaniv

name: Audio descriptions
body:
A short screencast on this topic: https://3194273-6.mediaspace.kaltura.com/media/t/1_nfv6qa5bÂ 

I recently discussed audio descriptions at Kaltura Office Hours and thought I'd post about it here as well. Audio descriptions are narration added to or combined with the soundtrack to describe important visual details that cannot be understood from the main soundtrack alone. I discuss both how to order REACH v2 audio descriptions and how a Kaltura administrator can manually add an audio description track to a video. Iâ€™m hoping some community members may be willing to share some example audio descriptions or experiences with audio description.

Ordering an audio description with the REACH v2 3Play service

First - hereâ€™s an example video with an audio description created with the REACH V2 3Play service: https://3194273-6.mediaspace.kaltura.com/media/t/1_k5b3tt26Â 

If you are a Kaltura customer, you would work with your RAE to request that the 3Play Audio Description service be enabled and configured for your account and the appropriate REACH profile. Youâ€™ll also want to make sure your REACH profile is funded with REACH credits as it is a professional service. Once thatâ€™s done ordering an audio description uses the same workflow for ordering captions:

  1. Search for or select the video you want to order an audio description for.
  2. Select Actions â†’ Caption & Enrich.
  3. Select the REACH profile with the audio description service.
  4. Select Service â†’ Professional.
  5. Select Feature â†’ Audio Description.
  6. Select either 5 Days, 48 Hours, or 24 Hours Turnaround time.
  7. Select Submit.

Once returned the audio description will automatically be added to the video. You can select it as long as youâ€™re playing the video back with a Kaltura player that has the â€œaudio selectorâ€ feature enabled.

Adding an audio description manually

What if you want to use your own video editor to create an audio description track? How would you add that to a Kaltura video? This workflow is not for the end-user - it is only available to an administrator due to using the Kaltura Management Console and the API. But fear not! Itâ€™s not difficult. These instructions assume that:

  • You are a Kaltura Administrator with access to the KMC and the API.
  • You have already created an audio description file along with your original video. I can try to post something later about creating audio descriptions. There are some good guidelines on the American Council of the Blind website: https://adp.acb.org/guidelines.htmlÂ 
  • You have both the â€œEnglishâ€ and â€œAudio Descriptionâ€ flavors available in your transcoding profile.
  • You have a player with the audio selector feature enabled for playing the video with audio description back.

If you have the access and files ready - hereâ€™s how to add an audio description track to a video:

  1. Login to the Kaltura Management Console: https://kmc.kaltura.com/index.php/kmcng/login
  2. Search for and select the video you want to add an audio description to.
  3. Select the Flavors tab.
  4. Select the three dot button next to the English flavor and select Upload.
  5. Select the original video you uploaded and select Open.
  6. Select the three dot button next to the Audio Description - Eng and select Upload.
  7. Select your audio description track and select Open.

Once everything is processed you can load the video in MediaSpace and play it with a player that has the audio selector feature enabled. Once you play the video you can select between the two different audio tracks. The labels are probably initially incorrect and need to be changed via the API. Hereâ€™s how to change the labels via the API:

  1. In the KMC with the video open make note of the Asset ID of both the English and Audio Description - Eng flavors.
  2. Open a browser and go to: https://developer.kaltura.com/api-docs/OverviewÂ 
  3. Select the SIGN IN button in the upper right.Â 
  4. Sign in with your KMC credentials.
  5. In the Navigation search type in flavor.
  6. Select flavorAsset.update.
  7. Select the Try it out button.
  8. Enter the Asset ID of your audio description flavor in the id*:string field.
  9. Click the + next to object to display all the different fields we can update.
  10. Enter Audio Description (or whatever youâ€™d like) in the label:string field.
  11. You can also select another language:string if youâ€™d like, but the label is what will appear in the player if the flavor has a label.
  12. Scroll back up and select the Send Request button.Â 
  13. Repeat these steps on the English flavor if you need to.
  14. Reload the video - it should now play and allow you to select the audio tracks with the correct labels.

I mentioned that we discussed audio description at Kaltura Office Hours. If you want to review those sessions they are available here:

  • 4/13/21 Office Hours - https://eduteam.mediaspace.kaltura.com/media/t/1_hnvsddhj?st=2217Â 
  • 10/26/21 Office Hours - https://eduteam.mediaspace.kaltura.com/media/t/1_7yxhswm0?st=963Â 

You do need a login to eduteam to get access to the Office Hours recordings. If you donâ€™t have an eduteam login, follow the instructions here: https://eduteam.mediaspace.kaltura.com/officehours .Â

name: Attachment Entitlements in KMS
body:
In KMS attachments have the same entitlements as the media they are attached to, allowing anyone who can view the media to download all attachments with it. As an additional option, we would like to limit specific attachments further to specific users / groups.

For example:

Media X has attachments A, B and C. Media X is visible to group Instructors and Students.

All attachments are currently available to download to both groups. However, we would like to limit attachments B and C to the Instructor group only, while leaving the media and attachment A visible to both groups.

name: Input on video completion grading
body:
Hey community ðŸ‘‹. I wanted to seek some input from you all about completion grading. We've been asked multiple times in the past (and more recently as well as customers migrate from other platforms like Knowmia, for example) for the ability to have video viewing completion pass back to the gradebook. Instead of making blanket assumptions, or just trying to mimic what someone else has done, I wanted to seek some feedback from you all to flex your community muscle ðŸ’ª.

  • What are your thoughts and/or interest in that (there are some pedagogical, etc concerns obviously)?
  • How should it be controlled? Should every video adhere to this? Control on a per-video basis? Global controls? Per-course controls? All of the above and then some?
  • What should count as completion? 100%? What should happen when a user stops a few seconds shy of the end (maybe in impatience)?
  • How should this be presented in the gradebook?

Other thoughts? ðŸ’­

name: Idea Proposal: Subscriber Analytics
body:
There is no way for channel managers to see who is subscribed to their channels. This data is not even available in KMC or Kava.

I would like to propose adding subscriber analytics to the channel analytics in KMC and KMS. Our users want to export a list of user IDs who subscribe to their channels. It would be even more useful if there was a field that included when they subscribed, however, I don't think that data exists. All of this subscriber analytics would allow our users to monitor channel engagement and increase the use of the platform.

I believe this would be possible using the API call â€œcategoryUser.listâ€. You would just need to filter on Category ID & â€œpermissionNamesMatchAnd : stringâ€ = â€œCATEGORY_SUBSCRIBE".

name: Auto-failover users when a live stream fails
body: Currently when broadcasting with multiple, primary and secondary, streams, a user's player can connect to either stream to receive the live content. If that stream dies, the player stops playing, requiring the user to click play to force the player to find the other stream. The suggestion is for the platform to recognize there are multiple streams, autodetect the stream failure, and migrate users formerly connected to the failed stream to the working stream without user intervention.

name: Using the Shared Repository and increasing Category Limit to 200
body:
Hi community!

My institution (Queensland University of Technology - QUT) has recently adopted Kaltura asÂ ourÂ video streaming platform and we're exploring options to improve the user experience for our staff and students.

Can you please help us understand:

  1. How your staff use the Shared Repository e.g. is it helping your staff to share and reuse media?
  2. If you have experienced any issues with Kaltura's limitation on publishing a media entry to only 32 categories. If you have increased this limit to 200, what impacts did you accept? How do you manage broadly reusable media to minimise the impact on end-users?

Any guidance/suggestions would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks,

Tony W. (QUT)

name: Tagging and Taxonomy at the enterprise level
body:
If you are like me, you struggle with "tagging" media. Bloomberg being in the "Big Data" arena, one would think there was enterprise wide "Taxonomy." From what we have found so far there is not.

This posting is to start a discussion on how "Unified Tagging" can be accomplished, or is being accomplished.

I am pulling together a meeting, of who we believe are the key stake holders, when it comes to "tagging" media at Bloomberg. I will post highlights of our discussion here.

Looking forward to hearing from the community on how your are handling "Taxonomy."

name: Issue when generating embed codes for playlists in Media Gallery/Channel
body:
Relevant for accounts that use embed playlists in Media Gallery/Channels.Â Â 

Customer Care has identified an issue that occurs when generatingÂ embedÂ codes for playlists in Media Gallery/Channel. Specifically, a Kaltura Session (KS) string is added with a default expiration of 4 hours.Â Â 

This is causingÂ playlistÂ embedsÂ created since October 17thÂ to returnÂ one of the followingÂ errorsÂ after the KS string expires:Â â€œInvalid KS EXPIRED, Error -1, INVALID_STRâ€Â 

Workaround: An Administrator with access to the APIÂ TestMeÂ consoleÂ can generate aÂ KS stringÂ with a longer expirationÂ and replace the KS stringÂ that existsÂ in the embed code.Â Â 

  1. Navigate toÂ https://developer.kaltura.com/consoleÂ Â 
  2. Log in using your KMC credentialsÂ 
  3. Select the â€œsessionâ€ call in the left side menuÂ 
  4. Select â€œsession.startâ€ from the main menuÂ 
  5. Add your Administrator Secret from KMCÂ 
  6. Change â€œexpiry :Â integerâ€ to a longer integer (e.g.Â 31536000 seconds is 1 year)Â 
  7. Change â€œtype :Â integerâ€ to â€œAdmin [2]â€Â 
  8. Click â€œSend Requestâ€ button on the top of the pageÂ 
  9. Copy the string from the results sectionÂ Â 
  10. Once you have the new string, swap it into the embed code for your playlist.Â Â 

Resolution: Currently the fix for this error is in progress by ourÂ Engineering team as a top priority.Â The fixÂ is currently a candidate for the upcoming deployment on November 14th, pending Code Review and QA.Â Â

name: Zoom â€“ older Marketplace version â€“ incident on October 31st - November 1st
body:
We are posting a supplemental post here in addition to the current updates being posted on our Status Page here:Â Â 

https://status.kaltura.com/incidents/zskv3dwjg6vfÂ 

The purpose of this post is to answer questions about a) upgrading to latest Marketplace version b) the re-import process for customers who have upgraded.Â Â 

To recap, theÂ latestÂ status as of November 4thÂ is:Â Â 

What is the Current Impact:Â 

Zoom recordings using the older version of Zoom Marketplace integration were not imported into Kaltura between ~9 a.m. UTC October 31st until 9 p.m. UTC November 1st.Â 

Current Status:Â 

As previously identified,Â content was not received for the recordings during this 24-hour time period.Â CurrentlyÂ there is not yet anÂ identified solution in order to backfill these recordings. The team continues to evaluate options, but it will require more time.Â HOWEVER, please read the Important section below for a workaround option.Â 

Â 

IMPORTANT:Â 

As aÂ workaroundÂ to recover and re-upload your account's Zoom recordings immediately, you can upgrade to the latest Zoom Marketplace integration**.Â After you upgrade, you will need to contact Customer CareÂ in order forÂ us to complete the re-import process on your behalf. Please update an existing case or createÂ aÂ new case on the Customer Care Portal.Â Â 

Note that the re-import process will be a two-step process done byÂ Kaltura, andÂ will include reimporting content from October 31stÂ to present day, and removing duplicates.Â SoÂ for a short time, you may see duplicate Zoom content until the process has completed running.Â Â 

Once the processÂ is completed,Â we will update youÂ via your existing caseÂ soÂ youÂ canÂ verifyÂ too.Â 

Note:Â **To update the Marketplace version, simply click â€œdisableâ€ in the integration. Then click â€œenableâ€ to re-enable it. This will automatically upgrade the version.Â Â 

Additional setup details here:Â https://knowledge.kaltura.com/help/kaltura-video-integration-with-zoom-setup-guideÂ 

Please let us know if you have any additional questions or concerns!Â

name: FYI: in-Canvas Virtual Classroom Desktop Share broken w/ latest Chrome
body:
Hi all â€“ posting this for the community in case there is anyone else in the same boat.

Conditions:

_Windows 10; _latest Chrome (Version 94.0.4606.81) [as of Oct. 15, '21]

_Canvas-KAF; _Media Gallery; _Virtual Classroom config "newrowOpenInNewTab" = No

When you select Desktop Share from the Tools then click Start Screenshare, nothing happens. You just click, and nothing.

Per Customer Care: "this is a known issue, and our team has contacted LMS for further recommendation on the fix. This issue is affecting the latest version of Chrome, and apparently Vivaldi as well from what you have mentioned to me. There is a workaround for this problem, which is to launch the room outside of the LMS itself (new window). So, please right-click on 'Join Meeting' and select open in a new window." and "Also, there seems to be no issue with Firefox."

I confirmed the Desktop Share works normal in Chrome when you open the Start/Join Meeting in a new tab outside of Canvas.

â€“Cameron Z.

Cameron Z.

body:
Each option on the player (either in the top or controls container) either standard options (like the small play button or the time scrubber) or those activated via a plug-in (like the attachments - paper clip) should have options for show / not show on the player and placement on either top / bottom or left / right.

The system admin would maintain the table.

Dennis

name: Gadget Corner: There's a Light...
body:
Happy almost Halloween, thus the vaguely RHPS-inspired Gadget Corner post about lights!

Image credit: 20th Century Studios

Modern cameras and sensors are far more forgiving about lighting than they used to be. The digital (and then HD era) along with software processing has made it so most video will look at least "pretty good" even with terrible lighting. But you can seriously up your lighting game inexpensively (and safely) to take your videos to the next level without too much effort! Below are some budget friendly options for improving your lighting setups in some common situations. Also, the usual disclaimer: These are not sponsored items or links. The item links may be from Amazon but are for reference and information, and are not referral links. (It just happens to be where I got them.) I have no connection to any of these items and am not recommending them in any official capacity. These are items I have personally used and reflect my own opinions only.

Learning a bit about lighting theory will help, and while not explicitly necessary I'm going to tell you about it anyway. Becoming a lighting expert takes a lifetime, but a grasp on the concept of how 3 point lighting works will help you understand why, how, and where you should use lights. In the shortest, most simplified way to start thinking about it, great lighting will generally start with a system called 3 point lighting, which uses light coming from (unsurprisingly, given the name) 3 sources: Key light, Fill light, and Back light. The key light is aimed at your subject, slightly to one side, with the most intensity. The fill light comes from the other side and generally has 50-75% of the intensity of the key light. And the back light comes from (you guessed it) the back of the subject, from the side and above (usually) to give a little highlight and separate the subject from the background to create depth. Since this is a gear post I'm not really giving this the detail it deserves, but understanding the basic concept will help you pick lights and have some idea of where to put them. If you want to learn more about 3 point lighting, here's a couple of links to start with:

https://www.mediacollege.com/lighting/three-point/
https://www.studiobinder.com/blog/three-point-lighting-setup/

The point is, if you're going to throw some money at lights (even if it's only a little bit) it's good to have a general idea of where and how to position them. Also, you might have noticed I mentioned safety earlier. In the "old" days professional lights were hot lights. Besides being heavy and expensive, many of them got hot enough to set anything they touch on fire and melt the skin from any part of your body they touched. There is no need whatsoever to use those kind of lights anymore (for our purposes here) and even color-corrected fluorescents aren't necessary anymore. (While less dangerous, they're still heavy and expensive.) LEDs are cheap, cool to the touch, comparatively lightweight, can have great color reproduction (and even color shifting) for a fraction of the price.

Color temperature is another thing that we really don't want to dive too deep on, but it's important to have a basic understanding of color temp and CRI for LEDs. So this is another area where you can read much, MUCH more than what I'll write here. Color temp is measured on a Kelvin scale. Generally - a yellow/orange "warm" look (tungsten) is in the 27-3200k range, and white "cool" (daylight) is in the 5600k range. (You'll often see a similar scale printed on the box of the lightbulbs you're using right in your own house. Go take a look. Do it.) If you want a warm look, look for the lower range, and if you want a cool look get lights in the upper range. (Some LEDs will do color shifting across multiple color temperatures, which is a nice plus.) You generally don't want to mix color temps, pick a look and stick with it. If you have room lights you have to consider (like ceiling mounted fluorescents in your office) you can look up the color temp online to incorporate that into your other choices. (And again, modern cameras and sensors are very forgiving.) You can learn more about the color temperature scale here: https://lightingdesignstudio.co.uk/colour-temperature/

OK, one more theory item to talk about before we get into actual gear. CRI, or Color Rendering Index. Look for a CRI in the 90s (the closer to 100 the better) for better color reproduction. Cheap LEDs sometimes have a low CRI and will make you look like you're ill. You can always turn to Wikipedia to learn more: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_rendering_index

Despite my attempts to scale that all down, it's still pretty verbose. Sorry. I love to hear myself talk, even if it's just in my own head as I type. But anyway, for those of us with champagne taste on a Miller Lite budget, here are some lights I've bought and used personally over the years with great success!

Scenario 1: Sitting at your desk, in your home office, working remotely. This is my setup right now at home, my home office is setup in the basement, and I have a fluorescent fixture above me, to the left, which acts as both a key and back light (because it's 4 feet long and where my desk falls is about in the middle of it running front-to-back.) So if I only used that light I'd have very harsh shadows on the right side of my face, due to most of the intensity of the light coming from the left. There are other lights in the room, but they're further away and do little to add anything other than some minor fill. I'm using a Logitech c910 webcam which is a pretty decent sensor, but also old at this point (8ish years.) It gets the job done, but any webcam, even a brand new one, is still going to have a very small sensor that will be compensating for lighting on the software-side. That will add graininess, lack of detail, and probably lack of color saturation. So if you can light yourself well you can vastly improve the performance of your webcam recordings. I added this small LED ring light, clamped to the right side of my desk to add fill:

https://smile.amazon.com/Clip-Light-Reading-Lights-Brightness/dp/B07WMRQQQ7

Note that it has adjustable color modes and intensity/brightness and runs off of standard 5v USB power. (I have it plugged into the USB hub on my keyboard.) The flexible neck makes it easy to position and it remembers the last color/intensity setting when you turn it on. This particular light doesn't give a CRI rating, but I've found it quite acceptable for webcam usage. Also, the color settings only have 3 choices (rather than something variable) but it's worked out perfectly for my needs. (and it's $15) Since it's a ring light and on a flexible neck, you could even position it so your webcam shoots through it, if needed. Since in 3 point lighting you're looking for subtle contrast between your key and fill (remember we talked about how a fill light is lower intensity than the key light) so adjustable brightness gives you a lot of flexibility in fine tuning the look to create some contrast and depth without harsh shadows. Making your key and fill the same intensity will result in a flat, boring look.

I also have this one which I thought I might use as an eye light (which is a type not mentioned before now, surprise!) An eye light is used to cut the shadows you get under your eyes when lights are coming from above and you're not getting enough bounce or fill from other lights, so you see shadows/dark circles/etc on your eyes. (Not everyone agrees on eye light definitions, terminology, or use cases, like everything else with lighting, but this is how I've always understood it.)

https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B07HMCN3G6/

Ultimately, this small LED stick light ended up being unnecessary for me, as the color temp isn't adjustable and it was too far off from the other lights (and looked a little green on camera.) But the clip, flexible gooseneck, and 5v USB power are still nice features. So ultimately, just the room lights and the addition of the ring light helped immensely with improving the overall look of my webcam recordings for Personal Capture, Express Capture, Virtual Classroom, and anywhere else I use my webcam.

Scenario 2: Small Studio/One-Button Studio/Multimedia Space/etc.

This is another area where LEDs really shine for versatility, affordability, and safety. I spent decades (ouch, but I digress) using predominantly hot lights both in-studio and for location shooting. They can be expensive and unreliable (bulbs burn out at the worst time) but ultimately you can work magic with how they look. The biggest problem is safety - traditional studio lights will easily start fires and sear the flesh off your skin in seconds, so they're not ideal for a small, self-service space you might set up on campus. A mandatory part of any gaffers kit is always thick canvas gloves for touching/adjusting lights and housings, and a small fire extinguisher. (The Gaffer is the chief electrician on a set, and works closely with the director of photography or lighting director on lighting.) So on a small production, the person touching the lights, if not the DP, is the de facto gaffer. (insert themoreyouknow.gif here.) Anyway, for almost all of our purposes, none of that is necessary anymore. For any setup you're likely to put together, LEDs are the way to go. We used several sets of these for both location shooting and small studio spaces, and they're amazing for the price. They have a great CRI, are dimmable as well as color-shifting, and have real barn doors:

https://smile.amazon.com/Neewer-Photography-Lighting-Dimmable-3200K-5600K/dp/B08216G3NB/

I say "real" barn doors because, inexplicably, some low-cost LED lights use shiny, reflective metal barn doors. This is not what you want. Barn doors are meant to shape the light, not reflect it, and should always be matte black, never shiny. (*puts away soapbox*) For the cost, these lights can't be beat (there are other combinations without the battery adapters and light stands that can be about $50 cheaper, give or take.) I used them for several years and expect that they're still in use today at my previous institution. They look really good on camera, which you'd expect with a high CRI rating.

These are also a good option for an even lower budget, but also for unusual size constraints (sometimes you're trying to create a small studio in a confined space like a library study room or small office.) They claim a CRI of greater than 90 (but don't offer any specifics.) I might find that a little odd, but I've used these and they work out really nicely. They are super lightweight and can work great mounted in a corner using something like a wall mount right angle baby pin. (Prices vary greatly on mounting hardware, but you should be able to find them for ~$20ish.) They'll be much better in a small space than a light stand or wall mount arm.

https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B0722RSD3P

These stick lights can also be good for lighting up a green screen with some nice, even light for chroma-keying. But it's worth checking if you can get a clean key without them. I used to always light green screens independently (because it was 100% necessary to get a clean key) but I found in recent years that there is sometimes no difference with modern keying software. If the shadows being cast on your green screen from your lighting design aren't too harsh, you may not need anything additional at all to flatten them out. Give it a try in your software of choice before you bother lighting it independently.

For wall mounting any of these, a right angle baby pin like this is a great space saver:

https://www.amazon.com/Sunset-Foto-Angled-9x15cm-Studio/dp/B086TVD4JB

Make sure you measure the wall clearance AND check the weight of your lights, use the appropriate wall anchors for the weight. (I've used these right angle pins several times in different mounting situations with a great deal of success.) They have four holes for easy hardware mounting. The wall anchors at the hardware store (or anywhere else) will have a weight range on the box - find out what you need then buy the next size up. Always err on the conservative side when attaching heavy electrical things to your walls.

I've tried to make this all easily digestible, but it's still a lot to take in. The point is, there's a ton of budget-friendly gear out there if you think creatively and experiment a bit. If you have any questions please post below and I'll do my best to answer them. Also, if you have a specific suggestion for a future Gadget Corner post, let me know!

name: RAPT Interactive Videos - Ability to Save a Copy
body:
Unless there is some way to do this that I am not aware of, we've had a number of instances where it would be nice to be able to "Save a Copy" of an interactive (RAPT) video. The interactive video does not have this option, as it only has a "Save project" button. The only way to duplicate an interactive video project is to start a new one and manually recreate all of the object paths, timings, settings, hotspots, etc. This can be very tedious on more advanced projects.

The option to save a copy is available in the standard Kaltura video editor. Please add this to the interactive video editor.

name: Hello from Redlands, California
body:
Hello! I am the Multimedia Services Manager at the University of Redlands, which is about an hour and a half drive east of Los Angeles, past Claremont and before Palm Springs. We have a couple of graduate programs that do a lot of teaching and learning online, as well as a residential undergraduate college, which uses Kaltura to a lesser extent. I have been using Kaltura for a couple of years as a platform for videos produced by me, as well as by student workers whom I managed, and by students in a video production class that I used to teach. Now, I'm transitioning into a role where I will manage the back end for users, which will mean that most of my clients will be professors, and sometimes students. Our LMS has been Moodle for a number of years, but we are in the process of choosing either to stay with Moodle or move to another LMS.

There is a lot of detailed technical information about Kaltura, I've seen, but my hope is that, between my supervisor and the community here, I will learn what the most common and most important services are that I must learn to provide. Another thing that I hope to learn from this community of experienced users (and designers) is ways to better structure our platform for best organization as the number of users and videos keeps growing. Some examples of how other small universities structure their platform would be useful to me.

I'll see you around,

Nicholas

name: Gadget Corner:  HDMI to USB Capture Devices
body:
Hi gang! I thought I'd start some threads on a topic near and dear to my heart, cheap gear! These are all things that work with Kaltura, or at least are Kaltura-adjacent in some way. I have a great love for finding no-name gear and gadgets online and testing them to see if they work as well as advertised. In most cases I order from Amazon because of easy returns for Prime items (if it doesn't work) so no harm done other than time spent experimenting.

And when I say they "work with Kaltura" I am speaking from my own personal experience, I'm either using them right now or I have in the past (depending on the item.) So I am not representing Kaltura or any specific device (because the branding frequently changes, and the internals may change as well) but I can tell you about my first-hand experiences using them. Also, any links are purely for informational purposes - no affiliate links (from me or anyone else) but generally I get these items from Amazon. (With occasional forays into B&H, Adorama, etc.)

First up - USB video capture. I've used a LOT of gear over the years to get HDMI or SDI video signals into computers. There are a lot of great devices from major brands that are heavy duty and meant to run 24/7 in professional settings. They can be hundreds and even thousands of dollars, and they're devices I'd trust to put in classrooms, auditoriums, etc. These are not those devices. These are a few items I wanted to keep on my desk and place around my home office (connected to budget-action cameras, a story for another post) so I'd easily be able to use a variety of sources for Kaltura Capture, Virtual Classroom, Express Capture, Kaltura Classroom, etc. They don't run 24/7, but I do use them regularly and they serve me well. I have 3 total, the first are two of these:

https://smile.amazon.com/Capture-Streaming-Broadcasting-Conference-Teaching/dp/B09FLN63B3/

I have had these about a year, plugged into a USB3 hub that's plugged into my laptop. They take HDMI in and spit out a UVC compliant video signal. They are recognized as a webcam in anything that's looking for a webcam as a source. When I got them they were $11. They're still pretty inexpensive, you can look around and find a matching device under many different brand names for different prices, but (I believe) the internals are the same. These have been solid workhorses for me for close to a year, and allow me to show off different USB sources without conflicting with one another, such as in this Kaltura Classroom 4-input example. This is 1 Logitech webcam and 2 HDMI action cams plugged into the 2 dongles on input 1 and 4:

A few months into this I realized it would be useful to have another one for an additional input, but this time I sought out something with an HDMI loop through so I could add a confidence monitor, if needed. (And also to get one that was USB3, the others are USB2.) Unfortunately the exact model I got is no longer available on Amazon and I can't find one that matches exactly. Here is what mine looks like (you can see the other two dongles in the pic also, at the top - apologies for the dust.)


This also works amazingly well and adds an HDMI passthrough. I can run all 3 of these inputs and my webcam as a 4th input with no issue on my Windows laptop. I've used them with Kaltura Capture, Express Capture, Kaltura Classroom, Virtual Classroom, as well as other software like OBS to live stream RTMP to Kaltura. Just like with the other two, this presents to the computer the same as any webcam, and will be recognized in any platform looking for a USB device.

I've been using this for several months, also with no issues, simultaneously with the other two. Having a capture with an HDMI loop out to a monitor has been useful for an ad-hoc confidence monitor as well as reducing input lag for streaming devices where you might be concerned with input lag. :D This specific device doesn't seem to be currently available, but it was in the $35ish range from Amazon. This seems fairly close, but is not identical:

https://smile.amazon.com/Microphone-Loop-Out-Recorder-Streaming-Conference/dp/B09444NK3F/

But if I was looking to get something else to experiment with right now, I'd give that one a try. Happy to continue the discussion, questions, comments, or hear your own experiences!

name: Google Analytics for Kaltura Players
body:
Hi everyone,

I had an idea to start to pull out some of the things we've discussed in Kaltura Office Hours and add them to the Kaltura Community. This topic seemed to generate interest from a couple participants - I'm hoping to hear more on if or how you're using Google Analytics with Kaltura players. A couple resources:

I created a Google Doc which is a duplicate of the instructions here: https://bit.ly/3nEVFot

I also created a short screencast on the topic: https://bit.ly/39dg0J2

I'm not a Google Analytics expert but I learned enough with the help of my former colleague Peter Burke that I was able to connect Google Analytics up to our players at my former institution when I was a Kaltura admin. I found them to be a great help - particularly in determining what players were in use, and some live stats on how many users were viewing Kaltura media with players connected to Google Analytics. They are a nice add-on to Kaltura's own analytics.

Before we start I should note that if you have data governance or security experts on campus you should check with them before enabling or integrating Google Analytics with your production instance players.

Create a Google Analytics account

These instructions assume youâ€™ve never used Google analytics before and need to create an account and analytics property:

  1. Go to https://analytics.google.com/Â 
  2. Click Start measuring if you havenâ€™t worked with Google Analytics before.
  3. Enter an Account name.Â 
  4. Select the Account Data Sharing Settings that work for you.
  5. Click Next.
  6. Enter a Property name.
  7. Make sure the Reporting time zone lines up with your time zone.
  8. By default Google Analytics will have you create a Google Analytics 4 property to measure your data. We want Google Universal Analytics / v3 - click Show advanced options. Click the switch next to Create a Universal Analytics property.
  9. Next to Website URL enter the MediaSpace or LMS URL you want to measure Kaltura data from. While you will get analytics on plays from other domains, certain Google Analytics will only be collected from the domain you enter here.
  10. Select the Create a Universal Analytics property only radio button.
  11. Select an Industry category.
  12. Select your Business size.
  13. Select the checkboxes next to How do you intend to use Google Analytics with your business?Â 
  14. Click Create.
  15. Read and consider the Google Analytics Terms of Service Agreement. If you accept check the checkboxes and click I Accept.
  16. Check or uncheck the email options. Click Save.

  18. You now have your first Google Universal Analytics tracking ID (also known as an â€œurchin codeâ€) to use with your Kaltura player!


Configuring a Kaltura player to use a Google Universal Analytics tracking ID

These instructions show you how to connect Google Analytics up to your Kaltura players. Itâ€™s best to do this with each player - the only thing that changes is the â€œEvents default categoryâ€ which we recommend you use your player name with.

  1. Login to your KMC: https://kmc.kaltura.com/index.php/kmcng/Â 
  2. Click on Studio.
  3. Find the player you want to configure to send data to Google Analytics. Click on it.
  4. Click the chart icon on the left.
  5. Click the checkbox next to Google analytics.
  6. Click the arrow next to Google analytics to expand it.
  7. Enter your Google Universal Analytics Tracking ID in the Google urchin code field.
  8. In Event monitor function name enter: trackFunc
  9. In Custom events list enter: doPlay,relatedVideoSelect,playerReady,NoSourcesCustomError,bufferEndEvent,mediaError,embedPlayerError
  10. In Events default category enter the player name.Â 
  11. In Label override enter: {mediaProxy.entry.referenceId}|{mediaProxy.entry.name}|{mediaProxy.entry.id}|{configProxy.kw.id}|{configProxy.kw.uiConfId}
  12. Check Allow linker.
  1. Click Save Player Settings.
  2. Continue this process on all other Kaltura players you want to track usage on.


Using your Kaltura player Google Analytics

Now that youâ€™ve connected your Google Analytics to your Kaltura players, what sort of data is available?

Generating a report on player usage

One of the best reasons to connect Google Analytics to your Kaltura players is that you can see how much each of your Kaltura players is being used.Â 

  1. From Google Analytics make sure you have selected the appropriate account from the top menu.
  2. Under Reports on left click Behavior â†’ Events â†’ Overview
  3. Customize the date range in the upper right.
  4. Click view full report in the lower right to display more rows.
  5. Click EXPORT in the upper right to export your data to a PDF, Google Sheets, Excel, or CSV.

This is long enough so I'm going to leave it at this but I'm hoping others will chime in on if they're using Google Analytics with Kaltura players, and what sort of data and reports they find useful. Have a great weekend!

name: Did You Know - Health check
body:
For a quick Health check or review of Kaltura KAF/LMS or Mediaspace admin settings is below. Some settings we noticed are not always enabled in customer KAF/KMS:

  • AccessibilityÂ â€“ allow users to toggle contrast on/off
  • AttachmentsÂ allow media owner to attach files to their content
  • HistoryÂ â€“ return to viewing where you left offÂ 
  • HotspotsÂ â€“overlay links to content
  • HostedÂ module â€“ LTI role mapping and so many other things
  • Channel moderationÂ â€“ content wonâ€™t be visible until approved by channel moderator/content owner for specific category
  • ChaptersÂ module is usually enabled by default, however, support for full deck is not (at least in KAF)
  • SchedulingÂ â€“ allow faculty to set when video will be available to view
  • PlayerÂ module: Main player vs Edit player where you can allow content owner to download video
  • BSE move from v2 to v3Â â€“ browse and embed new UI, latest versionÂ 

More information can be found in the Knowledge Center - Basic Health Check or with your CSM. Weâ€™re here to help!

name: Kaf links work for authenticated users who are not members of site where published?
body:
We have discovered (due to a report from a faculty member and our subsequent testing) that KAF links (for videos published only to a Canvas course site) allow viewing by users who are not members of that course site.

So, for example, a member of a site can copy a kaf link (by right-clicking the video's title) in a Media Gallery, and then share that link with others who are not members of the site. The link allows for viewing by the non-member as long as that non-member has recently accessed some other Media Gallery (one in a site which they are a member). Besides this being a potential FERPA violation (if, for example, the videos include recordings of students), faculty are under the impression that their content is restricted to those who are members of the site to which theyâ€™ve published.

We've opened a Case about this (and reached out to our RAE), but haven't heard back, and I'm having a tough time believing this wouldn't have been an issue at other institutions, so hoping that there's some KAF config setting we might be missing, and that we can fix it in short order.

Judy

name: Zoom/Kaltura: Add Zoom Meeting Alternate Hosts to Entry Permissions and Notifications
body:
Hello again!

On August 16th, Penn StateÂ took the jump and fully embraced the newest Zoom/Kaltura Marketplace Integration. We've have been phasing out our university's dependence on Zoom cloud storage and encouraging everyone to use Kaltura for sharing their Zoom recordings. Since then many people here have missed the feature in Zoom that I think Kaltura can help with.

Problem:

Several departments have administrative professionals, learning designers, or other support staff schedule Zoom meetings on behalf of another person, while adding themselves as an alternate host. There are also people that include others as alternate hosts to assist with managing the meeting, and/or the recording within Zoom.

Since Penn State has encouraged our students, staff, and faculty to use Kaltura for long-term storage for Zoom recordings, many users are looking for this same functionality in Kaltura. The meeting host would like to have their alternate hosts to be able to access their recording in Kaltura without requiring the entry owner (Zoom meeting host) to log in to Kaltura and give the person co-editor/co-publisher permissions.

Suggested Solutions:

We suggest adding the following features to occur within Kaltura when a person is an alternate host for a Zoom meeting:

  1. Â If configured in the Zoom/Kaltura integration to do so, automatically add the Zoom meetingâ€™s alternate hosts as co-editors to the entry so the entry appears in their "My Media"
  2. If the â€œYour entry is readyâ€ notifications are enabled in Kaltura and #1 is enabled, send the same notification to co-editors for the entry.

Details for Suggestion 1:

In the Zoom Integration settings in the Kaltura Management Console (KMC), add setting to automatically add alternate hosts as co-editors to the entry.

Mockup of the proposed Zoom Integration settings in the KMC for alternate hosts

If the Kaltura Admin selects â€œAdd as Co-Publishersâ€ or â€œAdd as Co-Editorsâ€ in the integration settings, then the alternate hosts get access to the entry based on their selection. Alternate hosts information can be retrieved in the meeting information via the Zoom API.

Example of the alternative host in the meeting details via the API

Details for Suggestion 2:

If suggestion one and â€œYour entry is readyâ€ email notifications are enabled, add alternate hosts as a carbon- copy (cc) to the email notification.

What is the community's thoughts on this idea?

name: Idea Proposal: Improved IVQ admin functionality in KMC
body:
Kaltura admins have found themselves frustrated by the lack of admin functionality in KMC for Interactive Video Quizzing (IVQ). Specifically, analytics related to IVQ are available exclusively through the front end user dashboards (KMS/KAF), and the ability to manage a quiz (add/remove a question, delete a user's response, etc.) are, equally, only available through KMS/KAF. So when a user requests assistance with any of these functions, an admin must assign themselves as a co-editor or owner of the entry in order to manage it on the user's behalf through KMS/KAF, as none of these functions can be accomplished through KMC.

Adding this functionality to KMC would streamline workflows and allow admins to better support their users.

Thank you,

Raul @ Oregon State
